alert.note: Alert for Haines Borough and Klukwan (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued October 01 at 11:29AM AKDT by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 AM AKDT SUNDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...The following area, Northern Inner Channels. * WHEN...Until 100 AM AKDT Sunday. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. River or stream flows are elevated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1125 AM AKDT, satellite estimates and rain gauge data indicate heavy rain across the advisory area. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, especially near the Chilkat and Klehini Rivers along with Porcupine Creek. The heaviest rainfall is over and scattered showers will continue into the afternoon. - Areas around mile post 14 and 24 of the Haines Highway and around Porcupine Creek is the most likely place to experience minor flooding. - For Chilkat River at Klukwan: At 10:00am the stage was 126.71 feet. Flood Stage is 128.0 feet. Forecast: A crest around 127.92 feet is expected around 10:00pm Saturday. Impacts: At 127.0 feet: This is bankfull stage, but water can encroach the Haines Highway, south of Klukwan. Note that the Chilkat River is highly braided, if and when it shifts channels, our present bankfull and flood stages will be outdated. At 128.0 feet: Water will begin to flow over the driveway into the property of Chilkat River Adventures just upstream of the Chilkat River bridge. Additionally minor flooding may occur near 14 mile and 25 mile boat launches along with minor flooding of Porcupine Road. At 128.5 feet: Water will flood the property of Chilkat River Adventures just upstream of the Chilkat River bridge with some other minor flooding near 14 mile and 25 mile boat launches and along Porcupine Road. - If you live or recreate along Chilkat River or Porcupine Creek stay alert and be prepared to take action.
info.instruction: Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.
